awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Data-Driven Modeling and Preview-Based Control for Cyber-Physical System Safety
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop the theory and algorithmic tools for the design of provably-safe controllers that can leverage preview information from different sources. Many autonomous or semi-autonomous cyber-physical systems (CPS) are equipped with mechanisms that provide a window of projecting into the future. These mechanisms can be forward looking sensors like cameras (and corresponding perception algorithms), map information, forecast information, or more complicated predictive models of external agents learned from data. Through these mechanisms, at run-time, the systems have a preview of what lies ahead. Leveraging this information to improve performance of CPS while keeping strong guarantees on their safety, therefore, holds great promise for multiple technologies of national interest. We will use driver-assist systems in connected vehicles as the main application. Education and outreach activities will involve undergraduate and graduate students along with stakeholders from local automotive companies.

To develop the theory for learning- and prediction-enabled safety for CPS we will: (i) develop a modeling formalism, namely preview automata, for systems with preview information and correct-by-construction control algorithms that consider structured inaccuracies in the predictions for resilience; (ii) investigate how cooperation can assist in enriching the preview information; (iii) learn, via finite-sample data analysis, trustworthy dynamical models of the behaviors of non-cooperative agents with provable uncertainty bounds; and (iv) design methods for selecting compatible models from the learned dynamical models and for deriving safe controllers in the presence of cooperative and non-cooperative agents. Our innovations will enable safety-critical CPS to take full advantage of emerging technologies on sensing, perception, communication, and learning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many autonomous or semi-autonomous cyber-physical systems are equipped with mechanisms that provide a window of projecting into the future. These mechanisms can be forward looking sensors such as cameras and LIDAR (and corresponding perception algorithms), map information, forecast information, or more complicated predictive models of external agents learned from data. Through these mechanisms, the systems have a preview of what lies ahead at run-time. Leveraging this information to improve performance and adaptability of the cyber-physical systems while keeping strong guarantees on their safety, therefore, holds great promise. This project developed the theory and associated algorithmic tools for the design of provably-safe controllers that can leverage the preview information from different sources. 

Major contributions include:

  1. The effect of future predictions on the safety of autonomous systems is characterized using invariant sets. In particular, it is shown that the value of predictive information in terms of safety decays exponentially with the prediction horizon for linear systems.  The importance of this result lies in (i) its ability to inform the design and selection of sensors and prediction algorithms; (ii) its application in determining the horizon in model-predictive control to trade-off having a large safe operating region with the speed of computation.

  2. Theoretical and algorithmic analysis of learning predictive models such as transformers and Markov Jump systems is performed. Probabilistic bounds  on the prediction accuracy of such models are obtained. The importance of this result is that it makes it possible to integrate such models as predictors in control loops while still providing guarantees on the overall performance. 

  3. Another line of work focused on synthesis of control and learning methods for safety-critical systems in the presence of constraints and uncertainty. Adaptation laws for learning linear and nonlinear disturbances within fixed time horizons are developed, along with safety controllers that incorporate learned models and future system trajectory predictions to maintain safety and performance guarantees. It is shown how to quantify the uncertainty of the learning and adaptation laws using conformal prediction techniques, and account for this uncertainty in the synthesis of the safety controllers. The results apply to both single-agent and multi-agent settings. The significance of this work is its ability to enable the design of controllers for autonomous systems with certain safety and performance guarantees.

The results of the project were published in archival journals and conference proceedings, and disseminated via invited talks. The collaborative nature of the project led to cross-institutional publications. 

This project contributed to the training of several undergraduate and graduate students, and a postdoctoral fellow at the University of Michigan in the important area of safe design of learning and prediction-enabled cyber-physical systems.
